properties.Name: BondDuration
properties.Description:
Duration is a measurement of how long in years it takes for the price of a bond to be repaid by its internal cash flows. 

It is an important measure for investors to consider, as bonds with higher durations are more risky and have higher price volatility than bonds with lower durations.

Ex:
-  A zero-coupon bond has a duration = it's maturity
-  A vanilla bond has a duration less than it's time to maturity because coupon/interest payments are made during it's lifetime.

Duration changes as the coupons are paid to the bondholder

Duration increases immediately on the day a coupon is paid, but throughout the life of the bond, the duration is continually decreasing as time to the bond's maturity decreases. 

Besides the movement of time and the payment of coupons, there are other factors that affect a bond's duration: the coupon rate and its yield. 

Bonds with high coupon rates and in turn high yields will tend to have lower durations than bonds that pay low coupon rates, or offer a low yield. This is because when a bond pays a higher coupon rate, or has a high yield, the holder of the security receives repayment for the security at a faster rate.

Columns.Name: BondId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Financial Product.

Columns.Name: DurationCalculationMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Duration Calculation Method.

Columns.Name: Date
Columns.Description: Duration changes as the coupons are paid to the bondholder.    Therefore the date at which the duration is calculated must be known.

Columns.Name: Duration
Columns.Description: The duration of the bond as calculated by the associated Duration Calculation Method.

Properties.Description:
Duration is a measurement of how long in years it takes for the price of a bond to be repaid by its internal cash flows.
